description.narrative: The goal of the BCtA is to accelerate progress towards the MDGs by encouraging companies to adapt their business models to improve the lives of people while leveraging their core business expertise and realizing commercial success.

participating-org.narrative: SWISS AGENCY FOR DEVELOPMENT AND COOPERATION - SDC
UNITED STATES AGENCY FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT (USAID)

condition.narrative: UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
OUTPUT 1: Increased number of companies with inclusive business commitments - Number of members - Number of countries with BCtA member initiatives - Number of countries home to BCtA member headquarters - Number of high potential prospective member companies that BCtA has encouraged to consider IB annually ~ - Number of IB workshops: - Number of Outreach Events A) Participation-only Events: To be tracked going forward B) BCtA Co-Branded Events: To be tracked going forward - Number of enquiries about membership from non-members: To be tracked going forward
OUTPUT 2: Increased linkages between inclusive businesses, funders, and other resources - Percent of BCtA member companies consulted - Percent of BCtA members benefiting from referrals made (based on member needs/requests) - Number of linkages leading to: ? Business to business partnerships: To be tracked going forward ? Joint donor and business programs: To be tracked going forward ? Financing for members: To be tracked going forward ? Technical assistance for businesses: To be tracked going forward
Ratings of value of BCtA services to companies (based on member survey and interviews) N/A
OUTPUT 3: Improved tools and methods for measurement of inclusive business impact - Number of companies receiving any BCtA services in impact measurement assistance: - Assessment of how much companies value impact measurement tools (based on member survey) N/A - Mentions of a company’s IB initiative in annual or CSR reports To be tracked going forward - Percentage of members reporting results from IB initiatives: - Roll out of new mobile-based impact measurement tool: - Creation of new impact measurement framework: - Number of companies reporting improved impact :To be tracked going forward
OUTPUT 4: Creation and dissemination of more robust evidence on inclusive business - Number of knowledge products (case studies, sector reports, flagship reports) published: - Number of webinars and knowledge / s

comment.narrative:
OUTCOME A: Increased number of companies adopting business practices that are inclusive of the poor - Number of members adopting business practices that are inclusive of the poor (85) - Number of new members who are making an IB commitment for the first time (to be tracked going forward) - Increase awareness of Inclusive Business through advocating to private sector globally (To be tracked going forward)
OUTCOME B: Increased scale and effectiveness of existing business initiatives - Number of commitments by members (by total, existing, and new) (85) - Number of follow-on commitments (1) - Number of commitments that report growth (e.g., made new investments, moved to new geographies, or added products/services): To be tracked going forward - Number of commitments reporting increases in profitability: To be tracked going forward - Number of companies that report using BCtA’s mobile-based impact measurement tool to refine their initiative To be tracked going forward - Index of IB effectiveness (via survey, methodology to be developed. Questions could include whether initiatives are sustainable, successful in meeting company corporate goals, and successful in meeting development impact) To be tracked going forward
OUTCOME C: Improved adoption of inclusive business practices among the development community and local governments - Number of BCtA partnerships with development community: 3 partnerships (BIF/IAP, ANDE, GSB) - Number of Institutional Affiliates To be tracked going forward - Inclusion of IB in post-MDG agenda (Y/N) Yes - Number of country-level partnerships launched due to BCtA country-level efforts 0 - Increase awareness of IB with development community and local governments To be tracked going forward
OUTPUT 1: Increased number of companies with inclusive business commitments - Number of members 85 total - Number of countries with BCtA member initiatives 48 - Number of countries home to BCtA member headquarters 25 - Number of high potential

Growing our Membership Base Demonstrating the Power of Inclusive Business for the SDGs 1. By June 2019, increase BCtA membership base to 235 companies with high quality, innovative, scalable IB commitments (cumulative target) and 270 by June 2020. 2. Continue to build a strong pipeline of potential member companies and encourage them to consider IB models. 3. By June 2019, reach at least 80 companies through online and offline capacity building on the SDG/IB Maturity Tool and management practices (and 150 by June 2020). 4. Integrate the Insightly CRM system into everyday outreach and membership work by using it to organize data; track membership communication; identify trends in outreach and inclusive business opportunities; and streamline outreach efforts in general. BCtA’s country level work 1. Continue to carry out capacity building activities and deploy BCtA tools and services including SDG/IB Maturity Tool and Impact Measurement Tool in Colombia and Bangladesh. 2. In both Colombia and Bangladesh, encourage increased quality in private sector engagement in SDGs through inclusive business, growing BCtA membership in these two countries. 3. Continued engagement on IB and SDGs through knowledge products and advocacy; assess opportunities for further engagement through UNDP private sector events and network, provide relevant policy inputs through IB knowledge products. 4. Build a preliminary road map to roll out our tools and services in Tunisia, including key stakeholders and strategic partners. Building capacity of BCtA Member Companies and Inclusive Business to Measure and Manage Impact 1. 80 companies provided with online and in-person capacity building on impact management 2. At least 50% of member companies share annual progress report by end of July and 60% by June 2020. 3. Collaborate with key players in the SDG measurement space to further advance BCtA’s methodology and approach. Knowledge management and communication in 2019 1. Position BCtA Secretariat and its member companies as active thought leaders in the field of inclusive business through regular publication and distribution of quality content that addresses leading issues related to IB. 2. Maintain BCtA website as the go-to platform for the latest development and knowledge on IB, with a focus on promoting its range of tool-kits for IB. 3. Continue growing social media audience following and interaction across BCtA accounts to support Objective 2 (above) and reach and engage diverse and strategic online audiences. 4. Advance BCtA knowledge management systems to efficiently capture the explicit and tacit knowledge produced by BCtA, its members, partners and relevant stakeholders, and ensure the strategic use of this knowledge to catalyze learning and evidence.

As of December 31st, BCtA is set to fall below its year 3 membership target with a cumulative total of 249 member companies and 262 IB commitments (including 3 recommitments) after welcoming 23 new companies. This is largely due to the number of companies which have been held up in their applications by the bottleneck in onboarding and due diligence. 36 companies are currently drafting or finalizing their applications or have completed them and are waiting for due diligence procedures to be completed. In 2019, 54% of the reports due were submitted by members, which is below the 60% target. This is due to technical issues with the reporting software, which was introduced in 2018. Once these issues are resolved, the reporting proportion is expected to rise. BCtA has continued to provide training to companies, helping them advance on their IB maturity journey and contribution to the SDGs. BCtA trainings in Berlin (10 companies), London (8), Lagos (19), Cairo (10), Utrecht (20), and Istanbul (3) were accompanied by 137 offline trainings, such that the target of 150 companies trained was exceeded. BCtA continued to play a significant role in global events, including the organisation of the 9th Annual Forum and participation in the MENA BoP Summit in Cairo and the Tunis Forum on Gender Equality, ii2030. BCtA provided 34 companies with the opportunity to speak at events and share their IB experiences. BCtA has also developed partnerships with UNDP COs and impact accelerator programmes, running trainings in Armenia, Bangladesh, Belarus, Indonesia, Moldova, and the Philippines with the support on COs. Twenty member companies are continuing on the Impact Champions journey, undertaking a full cycle of impact management with guidance from BCtA. 432 companies started using the Impact Lab (of which 40 percent completed Module 2) and we collaborated with UNDP country offices in Armenia, Bangladesh, Belarus, Indonesia, Moldova, and the Philippines to provide online and in-person impact clinics for 55 companies. A partnership with Impact Hub allowed 48 start-ups to receive training on impact management from BCtA. 37 members were featured in BCtA publications and articles, highlighting their work and results, and 18 of these were co-written by companies. These were then distributed through our partnerships with 3BL Media and The Guardian, which shared 63 stories in 2019. In September, BCtA launched the inclusive management practices tool and published the What does it take to go big? Management practices to bring inclusive business to scale report, which included 17 member case studies. The tool is specifically designed to support MNCs in the identification, characterization, and implementation of their IB objectives, and will include the benchmarking of progress against peers. A thematic focus on gender was promoted with the introduction of 6 gendered reporting targets and gender impact considerations for new members, with 33 member companies now being women-led. From the focus countries, BCtA added six new members in 2019 (two from Bangladesh and four from Colombia). In Colombia, the SDG Corporate Tracker has provided an important service through its standardized structure for assessing companies’ contribution to the achievement of the SDGs. In Tunisia, we have been able to develop a detailed map of the IB ecosystem through scoping following engagement with the CO. This will allow Tunisias addition as a focus country once funding is secured. BCtA also engaged an external expert to conduct a mid-term review of BCtAs activities and value to companies, conducting round-table events in Colombia and online in order to receive and incorporate feedback from members.

Growing our Membership Base Demonstrating the Power of Inclusive Business for the SDGs 1. By Dec 2020, increase BCtA membership base to 300 companies with high quality, innovative, scalable IB commitments (cumulative target) and 270 by June 2020. 2. Continue to build a strong pipeline of potential member companies and encourage them to consider IB models. 3. By Dec 2020, reach at least 170 companies through online and offline capacity building on the SDG/IB Maturity Tool and management practices (and 150 by June 2020). BCtA’s country level work 1. Continue to carry out capacity building activities and deploy BCtA tools and services including SDG/IB Maturity Tool and Impact Measurement Tool in Colombia and Bangladesh. 2. Encourage increased quality in private sector engagement in SDGs through inclusive business, growing BCtA membership by 12 by Dec 2020. 3. Continued engagement on IB and SDGs through knowledge products and advocacy through the delivery of training to 55 companies by Dec 2020; assess opportunities for further engagement through UNDP private sector events and network, provide relevant policy inputs through IB knowledge products. 4. Roll out our tools and services in Tunisia through key stakeholders and strategic partners, and thereby grow our membership base in the country. Building capacity of BCtA Member Companies and Inclusive Business to Measure and Manage Impact 1. 155 companies provided with online and in-person capacity building on impact management 2. At least 60% of member companies share annual progress report in June and Dec 2020. 3. Collaborate with key players in the SDG measurement space to further advance BCtA’s methodology and approach. Knowledge management and communication in 2019 1. Position BCtA Secretariat and its member companies as active thought leaders in the field of inclusive business through regular publication and distribution of quality content that addresses leading issues related to IB (5 document cases). 2. Maintain BCtA website as the go-to platform for the latest development and knowledge on IB, with a focus on promoting its range of tool-kits for IB. 3. Continue growing social media audience following and interaction across BCtA accounts to support Objective 2 (above) and reach and engage diverse and strategic online audiences. 4. Advance BCtA knowledge management systems to efficiently capture the explicit and tacit knowledge produced by BCtA, its members, partners and relevant stakeholders, and ensure the strategic use of this knowledge to catalyze learning and evidence.
